author: @chamangupta4624
text: Cross validation is used to adjust the hyperparamenters of the model ,  we actually divide the dataset into training set ( actual training set + validation set ) and testing set , after this division we hide the testing set and now we have to come up with a model with best hyper paramters , so we train the model on training set and test it on validation set , if accuracy isn't good then we adjust hyperparameters and again repeat the process from scratch , thus for training the model optimally the validation set acts as a virtual test set , we make best model on training set and then test it on test set , thus it gives us the correct accuracy value. if validation set wasn't there then we would have adjusted our hyperparameters based on test set only , and thus we would have seen the test set multiple times and thus at last the accuracy which we'll get will not be fully correct as not the model but atleast its hyperparamters have been adjusted to give higher accuracy on test data

author: @DB-in2mr
text: I always love your clips+ material and expression (great work and rithms!) but this time maybe you could have highlighted at least a couple of things in the end (and releasing 4 bams maybe!) : 1) k-fold cross validation that you presented is generally not the best choice for selecting "across algorithms" (although it is done regularly and erroneously). Basic k fold cross validation  (a resampling method indeed) is generally used by ML professionals (I am in this group)  for model tuning (that is averaging across test folds the best hyperparmaeter set ) only for the same single algorithm method: the selection/choice of an algorithm + its hyper-parameters  should never be based repeatedly on same test sets (even test folds!) as the real risk is an optimistic bias estimate or overfit (even with cross validations). In fact, if you want to chose/select both algos and hyper-parameters you would apply at least nested cross-validation where true error estimates are practically unbiased ((Bias in Error Estimation When Using Cross-Validation for Model Selection, BMC Bioinformatics, S. Varma and R. Simon, 7(1): 91, 2006)). 2) Alternatively splitting in training-validation-test set is still ideal to select algos+hypers in the validation set but then checking once for cross-generalization performance estimates on "unseen data" in the final test set. : )  nevertheless, you remain one most relevant and vibrant pit stops for statisticians, data science professionals and trainees alike : )  ciao Daniele
